definitions.definition: money that you pay to use a particular road or bridge

examples.text: the possibility of imposing tolls on some motorways

definitions.definition: the amount of damage or the number of deaths and injuries that are caused in a particular war, disaster, etc.

examples.text: Every hour, the news bulletin reported the mounting toll of casualties.

definitions.definition: the sound of a bell ringing with slow, regular sounds
a charge for a phone call that is calculated at a higher rate than a local call
to have a bad effect on somebody/something; to cause a lot of damage, deaths, pain, etc.

examples.text: Illness had taken a heavy toll on her.
The recession is taking its toll on the housing markets.
The pressure of fame can take a terrible toll.

wordOrigin: noun senses 1 to 2 and noun sense 4 Old English (denoting a charge, tax, or duty), from medieval Latin toloneum, alteration of late Latin teloneum, from Greek telōnion ‘toll house’, from telos ‘tax’. Sense (2) (late 19th cent.) arose from the notion of paying a toll or tribute in human lives (to an adversary or to death). noun sense 3 late Middle English: probably a special use of dialect toll ‘drag, pull’.
